channel.title: Earth Lab Data Intensive Classroom Modules
channel.description: A GitHub Jekyll Website maintained by Max Joseph and Leah Wasser

item.title: Introduction to the netcdf 4 File Format in Python
item.description: Learn how to work with MACA v2 climate data stored in netcdf 4 format using open source Python and the xarray package.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Practice Your Python Plotting Skills
item.description: This chapter provides a series of activities that allow you to practice your Python plotting skills using differen types of data.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Spatial Data Formats for Earth Data Science
item.description: There are two primary spatial data formats that are useful for earth data science, vector and raster. Learn about these two common spatial data formats for earth data science workflows.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Nathan Korinek)

item.title: Introduction to the HDF4 File Format in Python
item.description: MODIS is remote sensing data that is stored in the HDF4 file format. Learn how to open and manipulate data stored in the HDF4 file format using open source Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Nathan Korinek, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: MODIS, Landsat and the Normalized Burn Ratio Index (NBR) in Python
item.description: MODIS is a satellite remote sensing instrument that collects data daily across the globe at 250-500 m resolution. Learn how to import, clean up and plot MODIS data in Python
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: Learn How to Work With Landsat Multispectral Remote Sensing Data in Python
item.description: Learn how to work with Landsat multi-band raster data stored in .tif format in Python using rioxarray
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: NAIP, Landsat, MODIS and Vegetation Indices in Python
item.description: Learn how to calculate vegetation indices from multispectral remote sensing data in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Chris Holdgraf)

item.title: Use Time Series Data in Python With Pandas
item.description: Python provides a datetime object for storing and working with dates. Learn how to handle date fields using pandas to work with time series data in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Chris Holdgraf, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Calculate Flood Return Periods and Exceedance Probability in Python With Pandas
item.description: Python provides a datetime object for storing and working with dates. Learn how to handle date fields using pandas to work with time series data in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Matthew Rossi, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Introduction to Functions in Python
item.description: A function is a reusable block of code that performs a specific task and can help you to eliminate repetition and improve efficiency in your code through modularity. Learn how to write functions in Python to write Do Not Repeat Yourself, or DRY, code in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Introduction to Loops in Python
item.description: Loops can help reduce repetition in code by iteratively executing the same code on a range or list of values. Learn how to write loops in Python to write Do Not Repeat Yourself, or DRY, code in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Introduction to Conditional Statements in Python
item.description: Conditional statements help you to control the flow of code by executing code only when certain conditions are met. Learn how to use conditional statements to write Do Not Repeat Yourself, or DRY, code in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: GitHub for Collaboration
item.description: GitHub is a website that supports git version control and also collaborative project management. Learn how to use git and GitHub to collaborate on projects in support of reproducible open science.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Max Joseph)

item.title: Work with Scientific Data Using Pandas Dataframes
item.description: Pandas dataframes are a commonly used scientific data structure in Python that store tabular data using rows and columns with headers. Learn how to import data into pandas dataframes and how to run calculations, summarize, and select data from pandas dataframes.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Work with Scientific Data Using Numpy Arrays
item.description: Numpy arrays are a commonly used scientific data structure in Python that store data as a grid, or a matrix. Learn how to import data into numpy arrays and how to run calculations, summarize, and select data from numpy arrays.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Introduction to Working with Files, Directories, and Paths in Python
item.description: Writing code that opens files using paths that will work on many different machines will make your project more reproducible. Learn how to construct paths in your Python code that will work on any machine using the os package.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Nathan Korinek)

item.title: Import and Install Python Packages for Earth Data Science
item.description: The Python programming language provides many packages and libraries for working with scientific data. Learn how to import and install Python packages for earth data science.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Will Norris)

item.title: Custom Plots in Python
item.description: This tutorial covers the basics of creating custom plot legends in Python
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Chris Holdgraf, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Introduction to Plotting with Matplotlib
item.description: Matplotlib is the most commonly used plotting library in Python. Learn how to get started with creating and customizing plots using matplotlib.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Learn to Write Clean Code and Literate Expressive Programming
item.description: Clean code refers to writing code that runs efficiently, is not redundant and is easy for anyone to understand. Learn best practices for writing clean, expressive code in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: Get Started with Variables and Lists in Python
item.description: Python is programming language that emphasizes the readibility of code and provides many packages and libraries for working with scientific data. Learn how to get started with writing Python code.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Text File Formats for Earth Data Science
item.description: There are many text file formats that are useful for earth data science workflows including Markdown, text (.txt, .csv) files, and YAML (Yet Another Markup Language). Learn about these common text file formats for earth data science workflows.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Jupyter For Python
item.description: This chapter teaches you how to use Jupyter Notebook, an interactive environment where you can write and run code such as Python and add text that describes your workflow using Markdown.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Bash
item.description: Bash or Shell is a command line tool that is used in open science to efficiently manipulate files and directories. Learn how to use Bash to access and move files and directories.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Open Reproducible Science Workflows and Tools
item.description: Open science involves making scientific methods, data and outcomes available to everyone. Learn why open reproducible science is important. Discover tools that support open science including Shell (Bash), git and GitHub, and Jupyter.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino, Leah Wasser, Max Joseph)

item.title: Customize Plots of Spatial Vector Data in Python
item.description: When making maps, you often want to create legends, customize colors, adjust zoom levels, or even make interactive maps. Learn how to customize maps created using vector data in Python with matplotlib, geopandas, and folium.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Chris Holdgraf, Leah Wasser)

item.title: Spatial Vector Data Processing in Python
item.description: Common spatial vector data processing tasks include reprojecting data to a different coordinate reference system (CRS), clipping data to a specified boundary, and joining data based on spatial location and attributes. Learn how to process spatial vector data using open source Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Martha Morrissey, Chris Holdgraf)

item.title: How To Design and Automate a Workflow
item.description: Designing and developing data workflows can help you complete your work more efficiently by allowing you to repeat and automate data tasks. Learn how to design and develop automated workflows using the example of calculating a NDVI time series in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Max Joseph, Lauren Herwehe, Jenny Palomino, Joe McGlinchy)

item.title: How To Contribute to Open Source Software
item.description: Learn how you can contribute to open source software.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Max Joseph, Tim Head, Lauren Herwehe, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: An Overview of the Impacts and Study of Wildfire
item.description: The Cold Springs wildfire burned 528 acres near Nederland, Colorado, in July 2016. Learn about how scientists study the impacts of wildfire using field surveys and remote sensing.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Git/GitHub For Version Control
item.description: A version control system allows you to track and manage changes to your files. Learn how to get started with version control using git and GitHub.com.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Max Joseph, Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Practice Writing DRY (i.e. Do Not Repeat Yourself) Code in Python
item.description: This tutorial provides an opportunity to practice writing DRY code using loops, conditional statements, and functions.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Jenny Palomino)

item.title: Git/GitHub For Collaboration
item.description: This tutorial teaches you how to undo changes using Git and helps you practice collaborating with others on GitHub.com.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Max Joseph, Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: Get Started With GIS in Open Source Python Tools
item.description: There are a suite of powerful open source python libraries that can be used to work with spatial data. Learn how to use geopandas, rasterio and matplotlib to plot and manipulate spatial data in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Chris Holdgraf, Martha Morrissey, Joe McGlinchy)

item.title: Setup the Earth Analytics Python Environment On Your Computer
item.description: There are several core tools that are required to work with data. These include Shell/Bash, Git/Github and Python. Learn how to set all of these tools up on your computer so you can work with different types of data using open science workflows.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Jenny Palomino, Martha Morrissey, Will Norris)

item.title: Learn How to Work With NAIP Multispectral Remote Sensing Data in Python
item.description: Learn how to work with NAIP multi-band raster data stored in .tif format in Python using Rasterio
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Nathan Korinek)

item.title: Learn How to Work With Multispectral Remote Sensing Data in Python
item.description: Learn how to use spectral remote sensing data to better understand fire activity.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Customize Plots of Raster Data
item.description: When plotting rasters, you often want to overlay two rasters, add a legend, or make the raster interactive. Learn how overlay rasters to create visualizations and how to make interactive plots.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Nathan Korinek)

item.title: Intro to Lidar Data
item.description: This tutorial covers the basic principles of LiDAR remote sensing and the three commonly used data products: the digital elevation model, digital surface model and the canopy height model. Finally it walks through opening lidar derived raster data in Python
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: An Overview of the 2013 Floods in Colorado, USA
item.description: In this module you will learn about the causes and effects of floods as seen during the 2013 Colorado floods. You will learn how streamflow, precipitation, drought, and remote sensing data are used to better understand flooding.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Lauren Herwehe)

item.title: Introduction to using Twitter Social media data in Python
item.description: Social media data can be used to address many social and environmental issues and challenges. Learn how to use Twitter social media data combined with basic natural language processing techniques to better understand the social impacts and perceptions of natural disturbances and other events.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Introduction to programmatic data access in Python
item.description: In this module, you learn various ways to access, download and work with data programmatically. These methods include downloading text files directly from a website onto your computer and into Python, reading in data stored in text format from a website into a Pandas DataFrame, and accessing subsets of particular data using REST API calls in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Carson Farmer, Max Joseph, Martha Morrissey, Jenny Palomino)

item.title: Raster Data Processing in Python
item.description: Common raster data processing tasks include cropping and reprojecting raster data, using raster math to derive new rasters, and reclassifying rasters using a set of values. Learn how to process raster data using open source Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Chris Holdgraf, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Fundamentals of Raster Data in Python
item.description: The GeoTIFF file format is often used to store raster data. Learn how to to open and explore raster data stored as GeoTIFF files in Python.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Chris Holdgraf, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Use Vector Spatial data in Open Source Python - GeoPandas
item.description: Vector data are composed of discrete geometric locations (x, y values) known as vertices that define the shape of the spatial object. Learn how to work with spatial data in vector format in Python, including how to import, manipulate and map shapefile data. You will also learn how to reproject vector data into different coordinate reference systems.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Chris Holdgraf)

item.title: Understand Disturbance with Data - Flooding and Erosion
item.description: This module uses time series data to explore the impacts of a flood. Learn how to use Google Earth imagery, NOAA precipitation data and USGS stream flow data to explore the 2013 Colorado floods.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Martha Morrissey)

item.title: Introduction to Clean Coding and the tidyverse in R
item.description: When working with data, you often spend the most amount of time cleaning your data. Learn how to write more efficient code using the tidyverse in R.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Max Joseph)

item.title: Introduction to using Twitter Social media data in R
item.description: This module explores the use of social media data - specifically Twitter data to better understand the social impacts and perceptions of natural disturbances and other events. Working with social media requires the use of API's to access data, text mining to extract useful information from non-standard text and then finally analysis using text-mining workflows
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Carson Farmer)

item.title: Introduction to programmatic data access in R
item.description: In this module, you learn various ways to access, download and work with data programmatically. These methods include downloading text files directly from a website onto your computer and into R, reading in data stored in text format from a website, into a data.frame in R and finally, accessing subsets of particular data using REST API calls in R.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Carson Farmer, Max Joseph)

item.title: Don't Repeat Yourself: Remove Repetition in Your Code Using Functions in R.
item.description: This module will overview the basic principles of DRY - don't repeat yourself. It will then walk you through incorporating functions into your scientific programming to increase efficiency, clarity, and readability.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Max Joseph, Leah Wasser, Software Carpentry, Reproducible Science Curriculum Community, Bryce Mecum)

item.title: Clouds, shadows & cloud masks in R
item.description: In this module you will learn more about dealing with clouds, shadows and other elements that can interfere with scientific analysis of remote sensing data.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Megan Cattau)

item.title: Refine Plots & Add Variables to Rmarkdown Reports
item.description: This tutorial set covers some basic things you can do to refine your plots in Rmarkdown document. It covers plotting in grids, adding titles to plotRGB() plots and refining the width and height of plots to optimize space.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: R Source Functions - Efficient Programming
item.description: Learn how to source a function in R by saving the function in another R script.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Multispectral imagery in R - Fire & Remote Sensing Data
item.description: In this module, you will learn how to use multispectral imagery, a type of remote sensing data, to better understand changes in the landscape and how to calculate NDVI using various multispectral datasets You will also review spectral remote sensing as a passive type of remote sensing and how to work with space-borne vs airborne remote sensing data in R. Additionally, we will cover raster stacks in R, plotting multi-band composite images, calculating vegetation indices and creating functions to make the processing more efficient in R.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Uncertainty and Metadata
item.description: In this module, you will learn the concept of uncertainty as it relates to both remote sensing and other data. You will also explore some metadata to learn how to understand more about your data.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Create Maps and Custom Legends in R with ggplot and Base Plot
item.description: Learn how to create maps with custom colors and legends in both base R and with ggplot in R.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Spatial Data in R and Remote Sensing Uncertainty
item.description: This tutorial covers the basic principles of LiDAR remote sensing and the three commonly used data products: the digital elevation model, digital surface model and the canopy height model. Finally it walks through opening lidar derived raster data in R / RStudio
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Lidar Raster Data R
item.description: This module introduces the raster spatial data format as it relates to working with lidar data in R. You will learn how to open, crop and classify raster data in R. Also you will learn three commonly used lidar data products: the digital elevation model, digital surface model and the canopy height model.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Intro to Lidar Data
item.description: Lidar is an active remote sensing technique that measures vegetation height. Learn more about discrete and full waveform LIDAR and how to use LIDAR data.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Basemaps in R
item.description: This module covers using ggmap to create basemaps in r / rmarkdown and how to overlay raster data on top of a hillshade.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser)

item.title: Work with Sensor Network Derived Time Series Data in R
item.description: This module covers how to work with, plot and subset data with date fields in R. It also covers how to plot data using ggplot.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Data Carpentry)

item.title: Get to Know R
item.description: This module introduces the R scientific programming language. You will work with precipitation and stream discharge data for Boulder County to better understand the R syntax, various data types and data import and plotting.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Data Carpentry)

item.title: Clean Code & Getting Help
item.description: This module covers how to write easier to read, clean code. Further is covers some basic approaches to getting help when working in R. Finally it reviews how to install QGIS - a free and open source GIS tool - on your computer.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Data Carpentry)

item.title: Introduction to Version Control and Git
item.description: Learn about and how to use version control to back up your work.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu ()

item.title: Lidar Compared to Human Measurements: Uncertainty and Remote Sensing Data
item.description: Uncertainty quantifies the range of values within which the value of the measurement falls - within a specified level of confidence. Learn about the concept of uncertainty as it relates to both remote sensing and other spatial data.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Chris Holdgraf, Nathan Korinek)

item.title: Understand Disturbance with Data - Flooding and Erosion
item.description: This module uses time series data to explore the impacts of a flood. Learn how to use Google Earth imagery, NOAA precipitation data and USGS stream flow data to explore the 2013 Colorado floods.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, NEON Data Skills)

item.title: Link data, processing and results using R Markdown and knitr
item.description: This module reviews how to use R Markdown and knitr to create and publish dynamic reports that both link analysis, results and documentation and can be easily updated as data and methods are modified / updates.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, NEON Data Skills)

item.title: Set up R, RStudio and your working directory
item.description: This module walks you through getting R and RStudio set up on your laptop. It also introduces file organization strategies.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Leah Wasser, Data Carpentry, Software Carpentry, Reproducible Science Curriculum Community)

item.title: Introduction to Open Science Teaching Activity
item.description: A hands-on activity where students review a project for readability, organization, etc and identify key elements that would make it more usable and readily reproducible.
item.author: earth.lab@colorado.edu (Naupaka Zimmerman, Leah Wasser, Reproducible Science Curriculum Community)
